6py.title: Reference vectors
6py.text:
we can often describe vectors as being a combination of some other vectors, which can be scaled and summed to get our vector.  it is useful to have a small set of reference vectors that can be combined to get any other vector in the space. when this set is as small as possible for a given space, we call it a basis. the number of elements in a basis matches our intuitive notion of dimension

by choosing a basis, we can break down any vector in different components, each one a scaled basis vector. these scalars are called the coordinates of the vector. we can also 




#Combinations
It would be really convenient if we had a simple way to describe any vector in terms of a small set of reference vectors. For example, if we start with two vectors $x$ and $y$, then we can scale and combine them to get any other vector on the plane:

![basis example 1](http://imgur.com/pCIZChk.png)

We call this combination of vectors a [linear_combination linear combination]. For any vector $v$, we can split it into two components, one in the $x$ direction and one in the $y$ direction.

![v as a linear combination](http://imgur.com/3Vwy0P1.png)

The part of $v$ in the $x$ direction is $x$ scaled by $3$, or $3x$. The part in the $y$ direction is $4y$. So $v = 3x +4y$. We call these the components of $v$, and the numbers each component is scaled by are called the coordinates of the vector. So the $x$-coordinate is $3$, and the $y$-coordinate is $4$. 

We could alternatively use a different pair of vectors:

![v with different reference vectors](http://imgur.com/UIAXTsM.png)

Then we could take the _same_ vector $v$, and write $v = 2s - 4t$. Now the $s$-coordinate is $2$, and the $t$-coordinate is $-4$. 
The coordinates have changed, but the vector hasn't! 

reachable by reference vectors = span



# Basis
What's the problem with using $v$ and $-3v$ as a set of reference vectors?

![v, -3v, line](http://imgur.com/Zx37TUA.png)

Even though there's two vectors, we don't gain the ability to reach anything new with the second vector. This is because $-3v$ is already a linear combination of $v$. 

Similarly, if we used $x$, $y$, and $d$ as a set of reference vectors, we can see that adding the $d$ doesn't get anything new in this case either:

![x,y,d](http://imgur.com/uDy309G.png)

That's because $d$ is a linear combination of $x$ and $y$, so for any vector we wrote as a linear combination of $x$, $y$, and $d$, we can rewrite it without the $d$.

Ideally, we would like a set of reference vectors where each vector brings something new to the table. We don't want any of them to be a linear combination of the rest, a vector with this property is said to be linearly independent of the other vectors. A reference set in which all the vectors are linearly independent of each other is called a basis. 

The vectors in a basis can reach out to any vector within a particular space. This set of all vectors reachable by a linear combination of basis vectors is called a [3w0 vector space].  

## Dimension
What vectors are reachable if we have a basis with just one vector $v$?

![one dimension]()

Linear combinations of $v$ are just $v$ scaled by different numbers. So the vector space is just any vector in a line containing $v$. So a basis with one vector can reach a one-dimensional space.

Now if we have two vectors $x$ and $y$ in our basis, we can reach any vector within the plane containing both $x$ and $y$:

![two dimensions]()

So a basis with two vectors can reach a two-dimensional space.

You can probably guess that a basis with three vectors reaches a three-dimensional space.

![three dimensions](http://imgur.com/UMA0xQT.png)

We would like to define the dimension of a vector space as the number of vectors in its basis. Before we can do that, we need to make sure that every basis for a vector space has the same number of basis elements.

Well, let's say we have two bases for our vector space. then we can write all the vectors in the bigger basis as linear combinations of vectors from the smaller basis.

This allows us to accurately imagine a four-dimensional space, by conjuring four vectors that we define as being linearly independent, and using the vector space that they reach. Even though four linearly independent vectors do not exist in physical space, the same mathematical rules can be applied to determine different properties of such a world. In this way, math allows us to explore all kinds of strange, exotic worlds beyond our own, including vector spaces of any dimension. 

zero dimensions, just zero vector. why? well lots of facts about vector spaces and dimension are easier to prove if we can assume every vector space has the zero vector. this space follows all the rules for vectors and scalars, and is clearly not even 1-dimensional, so saying it is zero dimensional really makes the most sense

## Standard basis
good to have a standardized basis that everyone uses by default
that is x, y one 

normal basis, convenient for basis vectors to have magnitude one - called a normal basis

%%%knows-requisite([angles]):
orthogonal basis
all the basis vectors are at right angles to each other

orthonormal
orthogonal and normal basis
%%%

# Reference point
We can do a similar thing with points. We choose a particular point as the reference point, called the origin. We can now describe points by writing which vector will take us from the origin to that point. And we can describe the vector in terms of the basis vectors. 

![origin, basis vectors, vector to point](http://imgur.com/VrlNHSC.png)

$p = O + 2x - 3y$
These numbers are called the coordinates of the point. For short, we can write this just as $p = (2, -3)$  but it's really important to make sure that we are clear on what basis is being used, and what the origin is. In the $s, t$ basis we used earlier, and with the same origin, $p$ can be described as $(1,2)$

![origin, point, different basis](http://imgur.com/cVT7X0P.png)

 First, we will continue building on this foundation for a geometric context, which ends up being surprisingly versatile. Then as we learn more about vectors, we will see more examples of non-geometric vectors.
